instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message:
No liquid damage or drop damage, no previous work done on this Mac.
I get the appropriate light on the magsafe and it responds to SMC reset. No power to the machine though.

I checked <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and get 0.686V at F7140

Also get:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C4850</CAPACITOR>: 3.43v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR>: 3.43v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>: 0.622v

Then I got to <CAPACITOR>C7900</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7901</CAPACITOR> which are both hot, sizzling hot, alcohol goes poof right away.

Second time I run into components getting this hot and it stops me as I don't want to do any/more damage. Any thoughts on where to go from here?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message:
They are on PPBUS, safe to rip them off and let be. Only 1 of them will be shorted, look closely at them and you can usually see a crack in the shorted one. 

You are VERY lucky with these easy fixes...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message:
Hah you may have just jinxed me ;)
Easy fixes are nice but they donâ€™t make for a great learning experience.

Will inspect closer and remove the culprit shortly.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message: No cracks in either, they actually look perfect (though that may have been the alcohol on it that cleaned them), still remove 'em?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, responds to SMC reset
threads.message: If they are really the source of the heat and PPBUS is shorted then yes.
